channel.title: Artificial Intelligence on Yanir Seroussi – AI/ML Engineering Consultant
channel.description: Recent content in Artificial Intelligence on Yanir Seroussi – AI/ML Engineering Consultant
channel.copyright: Text and figures licensed under CC BY-NC-ND 4.0 by Yanir Seroussi, except where noted otherwise

item.title: Beyond good vibes: Securing AI agents by design
item.description: Summary of my talk on the paper “Design Patterns for Securing LLM Agents against Prompt Injections”.

item.title: Posting into the void – with guardrails
item.description: A LinkedIn post with little traction led to a surprising AI collaboration – proof that sharing online can spark unexpected opportunities.

item.title: Data moats, stealthy AI, and more: AI Con 2024 notes
item.description: Themes from AI Con 2024: data moats, stealthy AI use, Chatty’s UX revolution, and enduring fundamentals.

item.title: Don't build AI, build with AI
item.description: Building AI is hard and expensive. For most companies, the path to AI success is building with third-party AI interns and cheap AI cogs.

item.title: Data, AI, humans, and climate: Carving a consulting niche
item.description: Podcast chat on the reality of Data & AI and my consulting focus: Helping climate & nature tech startups ship data-intensive solutions.

item.title: AI hype, AI bullshit, and the real deal
item.description: My views on separating AI hype and bullshit from the real deal. The general ideas apply to past and future hype waves in tech.

item.title: AI/ML lifecycle models versus real-world mess
item.description: The real world of AI/ML doesn’t fit into a neat diagram, so I created another diagram and a maturity heatmap to model the mess.

item.title: Your first Data-to-AI hire: Run a lovable process
item.description: Video and key points from the second part of a webinar on a startup’s first data hire, covering tips for defining the role and running the process.

item.title: Learn about Dataland to avoid expensive hiring mistakes
item.description: Video and key points from the first part of a webinar on a startup’s first data hire, covering data & AI definitions and high-level recommendations.

item.title: Exploring an AI product idea with the latest ChatGPT, Claude, and Gemini
item.description: Asking identical questions about my MagicGrantMaker idea yielded near-identical responses from the top chatbot models.

item.title: Is your tech stack ready for data-intensive applications?
item.description: Questions to assess the quality of tech stacks and lifecycles, with a focus on artificial intelligence, machine learning, and analytics.

item.title: Dealing with endless data changes
item.description: Quotes from Demetrios Brinkmann on the relationship between MLOps and DevOps, with MLOps allowing for managing changes that come from data.

item.title: AI ain't gonna save you from bad data
item.description: Since we’re far from a utopia where data issues are fully handled by AI, this post presents six questions humans can use to assess data projects.

item.title: Plumbing, Decisions, and Automation: De-hyping Data & AI
item.description: Three essential questions to understand where an organisation stands when it comes to Data & AI (with zero hype).

item.title: Adapting to the economy of algorithms
item.description: Overview of the book The Economy of Algorithms by Marek Kowalkiewicz.

item.title: Assessing a startup's data-to-AI health
item.description: Reviewing the areas that should be assessed to determine a startup’s opportunities and challenges on the data/AI/ML front.

item.title: AI does not obviate the need for testing and observability
item.description: It’s easy to prototype with AI, but production-grade AI apps require even more thorough testing and observability than traditional software.

item.title: Artificial intelligence, automation, and the art of counting fish
item.description: Discussing the use of AI to automate underwater marine surveys as an example of the uneven distribution of technological advancement.

item.title: Questions to consider when using AI for PDF data extraction
item.description: Discussing considerations that arise when attempting to automate the extraction of structured data from PDFs and similar documents.

item.title: Two types of startup data problems
item.description: Classifying startups as ML-centric or non-ML is a helpful exercise to uncover the data challenges they’re likely to face.

item.title: Avoiding AI complexity: First, write no code
item.description: Two stories of getting AI functionality to production, which demonstrate the risks inherent in custom development versus starting with a no-code approach.

item.title: Nudging ChatGPT to invent books you have no time to read
item.description: Getting ChatGPT Plus to elaborate on possible book content and produce a PDF cheatsheet, with the goal of learning about its capabilities.

item.title: Future software development may require fewer humans
item.description: Reflecting on an interview with Jason Warner, CEO of poolside.

item.title: New decade, new tagline: Data & AI for Impact
item.description: Shifting focus to ‘Data & AI for Impact’, with more startup-related content, increased posting frequency, and deeper audience engagement.

item.title: Artificial intelligence was a marketing term all along – just call it automation
item.description: Replacing ‘artificial intelligence’ with ‘automation’ is a useful trick for cutting through the hype.

item.title: Google's Rules of Machine Learning still apply in the age of large language models
item.description: Despite the excitement around large language models, building with machine learning remains an engineering problem with established best practices.

item.title: Was data science a failure mode of software engineering?
item.description: Yes, data science projects have suffered from classic software engineering mistakes, but the field is maturing with the rise of new engineering roles.

item.title: How hackable are automated coding assessments?
item.description: Exploring the hackability of speed-based coding tests, using CodeSignal’s Industry Coding Framework as a case study.

item.title: Remaining relevant as a small language model
item.description: Bing Chat recently quipped that humans are small language models. Here are some of my thoughts on how we small language models can remain relevant (for now).

item.title: ChatGPT is transformative AI
item.description: My perspective after a week of using ChatGPT: This is a step change in finding distilled information, and it’s only the beginning.

item.title: Causal Machine Learning is off to a good start, despite some issues
item.description: Reviewing the first three chapters of the book Causal Machine Learning by Robert Osazuwa Ness.

item.title: Building useful machine learning tools keeps getting easier: A fish ID case study
item.description: Lessons learned building a fish ID web app with fast.ai and Streamlit, in an attempt to reduce my fear of missing out on the latest deep learning developments.

item.title: Use your human brain to avoid artificial intelligence disasters
item.description: Overview of a talk I gave at a deep learning course, focusing on AI ethics as the need for humans to think on the context and consequences of applying AI.

item.title: Defining data science in 2018
item.description: Updating my definition of data science to match changes in the field. It is now broader than before, but its ultimate goal is still to support decisions.

item.title: My PhD work
item.description: An overview of my PhD in data science / artificial intelligence. Thesis title: Text Mining and Rating Prediction with Topical User Models.
